awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Workforce Development for a New Generation of Cyber Security Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP), through Targeted Infusion Projects, supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The University of the District of Columbia aspires to support the nation’s efforts to strengthen its cybersecurity workforce by enhancing the institution’s computer science curriculum and providing more opportunities to train more students to enter said workforce. The institution is well-positioned to impact large numbers of students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields.  Successful implementation of the project will establish a model for other analogous programs at peer institutions.

The project promises to: 1) strengthen the learning experience of UDC undergraduate students by developing three new cybersecurity courses that will be part of an interdisciplinary cybersecurity minor; 2) stimulate the undergraduate students’ participation in cybersecurity research by launching a summer cybersecurity research program; and 3) increase student enrollment and retention at UDC by implementing outreach activities related to cybersecurity, and by engaging existing and potential UDC students, recruited from local high schools and community colleges. It is expected that at least 600 students will be directly impacted, and benefit from, the proposed activities during the period of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_name: University of the District of Columbia
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of the District of Columbia

por.por_cntn:
This project at the University of the District of Columbia addressed the critical shortage of cybersecurity professionals by building a diverse and skilled workforce. The initiative focused on enhancing education and research opportunities, particularly for underrepresented students in STEM. 

Key outcomes for NSF Grant #2011689 “Targeted Infusion Project: Workforce Development for a New Generation of Cyber Security Systems” are: 

  1. Launch of a Bachelor’s in Cybersecurity: Initially planned as a minor, the program evolved into a full bachelor’s degree in Cybersecurity, launched in Fall 2022. This program integrates cutting-edge topics, practical training, and theoretical principles. It has gained significant traction, with growing enrollment and applications reflecting its success.
  2. Student Research Success: Students participated in summer research programs addressing real-world challenges, such as AI for cyber defense, blockchain-based security, and anomaly detection. These efforts resulted in thirteen peer-reviewed publications and presentations at prestigious international conferences and journals, providing students with invaluable research and professional development experiences. The student research also resulted in a master thesis in computer science tackling securing Android devices with Transformer neural networks.
  3. Innovative Course Development: Two new courses, Cloud Computing Security and Network Security, were developed and implemented successfully, offering students hands-on experience in securing critical systems. Despite efforts, the Smart Grid Security course was not developed due to faculty availability and low demand, but the program remains robust with its existing offerings.
  4. Community Engagement: Outreach activities, including guest lectures and high school visits, inspired interest in cybersecurity and encouraged students from diverse backgrounds to explore STEM careers. Adjustments to outreach strategies helped strengthen local community connections.
  5. Career Preparation: Students gained practical skills through research and coursework aligned with industry certifications like CompTIA Security+. This approach ensured that graduates are well-prepared for cybersecurity roles or advanced studies.

These achievements demonstrate the project’s success in fostering innovation, advancing cybersecurity education, and building a workforce equipped to address critical challenges in the field.

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Thabet Kacem
